name: Evia Forest Fire Emergency
description: A severe forest fire in North Evia (Euboia), Greece, spreading rapidly due to strong winds and dry vegetation. Multiple villages are threatened, with flames approaching residential areas. The fire has already consumed thousands of hectares of forest. Immediate evacuation and firefighting operations are critical to save lives and properties.

available_actions.name: Immediate Full-Scale Evacuation
available_actions.description: Conduct urgent mandatory evacuation of all threatened villages (6 villages, ~8,000 residents) using available buses, private vehicles, and boats for coastal areas. Prioritize elderly, disabled, and families with children. Establish evacuation routes with police escorts and traffic control. Set up 3 evacuation centers with medical support, food, and shelter. Enforce evacuation orders and document refusals. Estimated to save maximum lives but leaves properties undefended.

available_actions.name: Phased Evacuation with Infrastructure Protection
available_actions.description: Implement staged evacuation prioritizing immediate-risk villages (2 villages, 2,500 residents first) while deploying structure protection teams to defend critical infrastructure and remaining villages. Phase 1: Evacuate villages within 2km of fire front. Phase 2: Protect hospitals, schools, water pumping stations with structure protection. Phase 3: Evacuate next tier if fire advances. Allows resource optimization and selective property defense while maintaining safety focus.

available_actions.name: Intensive Aerial Firefighting Campaign
available_actions.description: Deploy maximum available aerial assets: 8 Canadair CL-415 amphibious aircraft, 6 Chinook helicopters, 4 medium helicopters with water buckets for intensive water and fire retardant drops on active fire fronts. Coordinate with ground spotters and meteorologist for optimal drop zones. Create aerial firebreaks using retardant lines ahead of fire. Operate from dawn to dusk with refueling rotations. High effectiveness but weather-dependent and extremely costly.

available_actions.name: Ground Firefighting with Firebreaks
available_actions.description: Deploy 250 ground firefighters organized in 25 crews to create strategic firebreaks using bulldozers and hand tools, and directly combat flames using fire trucks and hand-line techniques. Establish firebreaks along roads, ridgelines, and natural barriers. Use foam for structure protection. Deploy lookouts and maintain LCES (Lookouts, Communications, Escape routes, Safety zones) protocol. Sustained ground operations with crew rotation for 24-48 hours.
disadvantages: High crew risk in mountainous terrain
Limited effectiveness in extreme fire behavior

available_actions.name: Strategic Controlled Backburning Operations
available_actions.description: Execute strategic firing operations to create burned buffer zones between fire front and villages. Identify control lines (roads, rivers, bulldozed firebreaks), ignite from downwind side to create low-intensity backing fire that removes fuel. Use drone thermal imaging to monitor burn intensity. Requires weather window: RH >25%, winds 5-15 mph, consistent direction. Deploy qualified Firing Boss and experienced crews with drip torches. High-risk but potentially very effective if conditions allow.
advantages: Removes fuel before main fire arrives

available_actions.name: Combined Air-Ground Assault with Simultaneous Evacuation
available_actions.description: Comprehensive coordinated response: simultaneously execute aerial firefighting (Canadair + helicopters), ground firebreak construction, structure protection, and phased evacuation. Establish unified incident command coordinating all agencies. Deploy all available resources in integrated operation plan. Aerial assets suppress main fronts while ground crews establish firebreaks and structure protection teams defend critical buildings. Evacuate highest-risk areas while operations proceed. Maximum resource commitment for maximum effectiveness.

available_actions.name: Large-Scale Coastal Maritime Evacuation
available_actions.description: Leverage Greece's maritime capabilities for mass coastal evacuation. Deploy Hellenic Coast Guard vessels, ferries, fishing boats, and private vessels to evacuate 4,000+ coastal residents by sea from beaches and small ports. Coordinate with port authorities to establish evacuation points at Mantoudi, Pefki, and Limni. Transport to Chalkida and Athens ports. Parallel land evacuation for inland villages. Maritime evacuation bypasses congested mountain roads and can handle large volumes quickly if sea conditions allow.
disadvantages: Inland villages still need land evacuation

available_actions.name: Community-Based Defense Perimeter with Volunteer Support
available_actions.description: Engage local community volunteers (100-150 trained residents) alongside professional firefighters to establish defense perimeter around each village. Distribute portable pumps, hoses, and foam systems to residents who stay. Professional fire crews provide leadership and coordination. Create wet perimeters around buildings, clear vegetation, establish sprinkler systems. Residents defend their properties under fire service supervision. Empowers community but requires training and increases civilian risk.

available_actions.name: Strategic Retreat and Defensive Firebreak Establishment
available_actions.description: Pull back firefighting forces from advancing fire fronts and establish strong defensive firebreaks at strategic chokepoints 5-10km from villages. Use geographic features (rivers, roads, mountain ridges) to create defensible lines. Sacrifice burned area to ensure crew safety and create high-probability defense lines. Concentrate all bulldozers and crews on 2-3 major firebreak lines rather than fighting active fronts. Allows regrouping and ensures firefighter safety while accepting property loss in sacrifice zones.
disadvantages: Properties lost that might have been saved

available_actions.name: EU Civil Protection Mechanism Activation - International Assistance
available_actions.description: Activate EU Civil Protection Mechanism to request international firefighting assistance. Request aerial assets (Canadair, helicopters) from Italy, France, Croatia, and ground crews from across EU. Typically provides 10-20 additional aircraft and 200-300 personnel within 24-48 hours. Coordinate deployment through European Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC). Provides massive resource surge but takes time to deploy. Greece has reciprocal agreements and experience with EU assistance (used in 2018 Attica fires, 2021 Evia fires).
available_actions.estimated_duration: 24-48 hours for arrival, then 7-14 days operations

available_actions.name: Shelter-in-Place with Structure Hardening
available_actions.description: For villages where evacuation is impossible or refused (elderly residents, blocked roads), implement shelter-in-place protocol. Prepare buildings for fire impact: close all windows/shutters, fill bathtubs/sinks with water, move flammable materials away from buildings, seal vents, wet down roofs and walls. Establish safe rooms (brick/stone buildings with metal roofs). Deploy fire crews to each sheltering village for structure defense. Provide respirators for smoke. Last resort option when evacuation fails but better than unprotected exposure.
available_actions.estimated_duration: 2-4 hours preparation, duration of fire passage
advantages: Some residents prefer to defend homes
best_conditions: Fire crews available for structure defense

available_actions.name: Daylight Operations Focus with Night Safety Stand-Down
available_actions.description: Reduce or eliminate night firefighting operations for crew safety, focusing intensive operations during daylight hours (6am-8pm). Use night period for crew rest, equipment maintenance, strategic planning, and firebreak preparation in safe zones. Resume aggressive aerial and ground operations at dawn. Accept slower overall progress but dramatically reduces firefighter injuries and fatalities. Australian and US fire services increasingly adopt this approach for extreme fire behavior conditions where night operations are exceptionally dangerous.
available_actions.estimated_duration: 14-16 hours operations per day, 8-10 hours stand-down
disadvantages: Fire can advance unchecked at night

additional_concerns: Fire spreading at 3-5 km/h towards villages
Limited water sources in mountainous areas
Power lines down creating additional hazards

real_time_factors.wind_forecast: Strong northerly winds expected to continue for 12+ hours
